reviews.sentence: Great hotel with old fashioned James Bond style 1. Very welcoming and attentive staff. 2. Since the hotel was built in the 60s it is not the most modern hotel around. But the hotels facilities are well updated this making the old style of the hotel simply fascinating. 3. I went swimming a couple of times in the hotels swimming pool. Everything related to that activity was superb. To be highlighted is the restaurant connected to the swimming pool area and the fitness area. The young women working there are just outstanding. Arigato to them. 4. Parking is free and so is the perfect working wifi 5. The room I had was great in all ways. My only complaint is about the bed which I found too hard. 6. For me as a Norwegian I was really thrilled by the fact that the hotel has a bar in which it is possible to smoke cigars. 7. I will gladly return to this brilliant hotel.

A nice trip back in time. The Okura which is closing for re construction soon is a nice throwback to the 50s or 60s. The rooms are decent size shading to large the service good and most of the amenities were on site. You can avoid a daily gym charge by signing up for their rewards programs. They have a variety of restaurants on site most of which were pretty good. The hotel is also close to many government agencies and is right across the street from the US Embassy. My only complaint is that it was hard to control the room temperature. It was really hot when I got to the room and the thermostat did not seem to relate to the temperature. From the airport you can take one of two buses for 31 instead of a 300 taxi ride. One bus goes right to Okura. The other with schedule offset by 30 minutes goes to the ANA Intercontinental which is just a short walk away.

Nice hotel made very good by its staff. Stayed here for a couple of nights on a business trip. The hotel is well located in the diplomatic area and is a short walk to shops and restaurants. it is a bit of a grand dame of a hotel dark wood and large lobbies. Wifi is poor and sometimes unreliable when the occupancy is high but the staff are great and very helpful. I would stay here again.

BUT WORTH IT. Simply superb location and services on offer. expensive but what is not in Tokyo. Much better than many other establishments in this hotel chain in other cities countries. Relaxed environment and transport to airports on offer so no need for exorbitantly expensive taxis.

The Okura is still holding on. I am a diehard Okura fan please see my 2013 review for more detail and am one of those lamenting the recent closure of the main building whose inimitable 1960s aesthetic will be replaced by a new version of the hotel slated to open in 2019. Until then the Okuras South Wing built in the 1970s remains open. We recently had a four night stay my first since the main building closed last fall. A note on transportation to the Okura from Narita airport. The limousine bus route to the Okura seems to have changed. Instead of going to the nearby ANA Intercontinental hotel and then to the Okura as in the past our bus went to Tokyo City Air Terminal TCAT and Tokyo Station before arriving at the Okura. The new route is less direct and more prone to traffic. Even late at night the ride from the airport took nearly two hours when it used to take about 90 minutes. If time is important you might want to see if there is a route that takes you relatively directly from Narita to the ANA where you could then take a 5minute taxi ride to the Okura. Even with the loss of the main building the Okura attributes of attentive service and comfortable Japanese hospitality remain intact. That said on this trip some things felt figuratively and literally frayed around the edges. When the bus arrived at the hotel there were no bellhops on hand to help with luggage something I have never experienced before. Service during breakfast at Camellia Corner was slow and confused. The rooms remain immaculate with superior bedding but the carpets and amenities like bathrobes are starting to look tired. The concierge service was excellent providing fast and detailed information on a trip out of town and graciously helping with a difficult last minute restaurant reservation. The hotels free WiFi worked very well. I had not stayed in the South Wing in over a decade and the rooms are very similar to what was on offer in the main building. The lobby and other public areas still have the original 1970s design but the rooms themselves are more generic and modern. We did not notice any construction noise from the area around the main building and our eleventh floor room was quiet. The Okura is in the Toranomon neighborhood and is about a 10minute walk to two subway stations. While Toranomon itself is a quiet place dominated by office buildings and the nearby US Embassy the area is within walking distance of Akasaka Ropongi and Kasumigaseki where many Japanese government ministries are located. Even with the loss of its iconic main building the Okura is soldiering on. As much as I miss the magnificent lobby and other public areas in the old building the hotel still offers a strong combination of comfort service and location at a competitive rate.

Grand tradition. My favorite place in Tokyo. The greatness of the tradition can be found in every detail room restaurant front desk concierge. Breakfast is the same kind. genuine Japanese dishes along with western top quality offers. Great pool and well staffed gym club.
Great service nice hotel with a very good restaurant and spa amazing breakfast and near to two different metro station also walking distance from Ropongi.
Spacious room and attentive staff. One minor nit is that the toilet seat is not heated. My wife has grown to love that extravagance. This will be a problem when we return home.

Best hotel experience. The rooms are amazing. All facilities are modern and rooms either side of the hotel boasts excellent views of Tokyo. The staff are wonderful and helpful in every way. I would recommend the Okura hotel to anyone and everyone.

An excellent business hotel. You know Okura hotels are excellent satisfy every aspects of terms of good hotel. Every staffs of this traditional hotel are very kind with smiling faces. There are 4 subway stations within 1 km from the hotel convenient to go everywhere in Tokyo. This hotel is a little bit old. A new hotel building will be open in a monthSubway stations are not so close. The closest one needs 6 7 minutes to walk.

The fall of the mighty Okura. The main service part is still intact but with debilitatingly reduced facilities. The reduction in restaurants the closure of pool and spa facilities and reduction of staff to the level there ’s no help for your luggage. Most importantly all these changed were made without telling customers beforehand. Especially since my company has been staying with the hotel for over twenty years.

Okay. Rooms has windows which might be open upon request location in the city center but you need a taxi cleanliness is good but not a high standard. It ’s an old hotel with old furniture needs a renewal location is not really good but everything is 10 15 minutes by taxi which is provided by hotel staff are not very friendly rooms are overpriced compared to others no late checkout is allowed as you have to pay for 2 hours or half a night for more.

The hotel is being run into the ground before it closes zero facilities and sad staff. Real pity. Rooms are clean every taxi driver knows where Hotel Okura is. The hotel is tired and scruffy and it is being maintained by a skeleton staff because it is being run into the ground before it closes immediately after the olympics in 2020. The pool is shut the gym was shut during our stay all the shops have gone and the bakery that used to be next to the restaurant.

You do not get what you pay for. Rude people at the front desk that lies to you. Avoid at all cost.

the property is amazing traveling backwards in time amazing features the staff is reasonably competent at arrival language is an issue the practice of english is sketchy i was sent 2 technical hotels staff in my room shortly after my arrival to help with a computer connection problemFYI the connection to the internet via the hotel is very 1950s not great what so ever so hard to imagine staying there on business and. they both had deplorable hygiene no english no tech skills and when i she the one staffer went to reach for my computer i was shocked and disgusted to see his hands entirely covered in red bruises and putrefaction from biting his nails and skin. gross what it a skin disease it was a very uncomfortable experience one i do nt wish to anyone.
